content: pnw bricks hat by susan plack i have been spending time in the pacific northwest recently and am in love with the brickwork on the buildings this simple knit/purl pattern creates the texture that reminds me of the architecture in the pnw this hat has a simple 6 stitch and 6 row repeat that is designed to keep it interesting while being easy to memorize this hat can be adjusted to fit any size head or knit gauge by casting on multiples of 6 if you want a shorter or taller hat you can simply increase or decrease by knitting multiples of the 3 or 6 row repeat yarn weight any worsted weight the hat takes about ​ 30 grams for the newborn to baby size 40 grams for the toddler hat 55 grams for the child hat 75 grams for the small adult hat 90 grams for the adult hat 100 - 110 grams for the adult large some suggestions malabrigo rios abstract fiber worsted experience level beginner ​ sizing newborn to baby/toddler/child/adult small/adult/adult large ​ approximate finished measurements newborn to baby 12 5 circumference - 6 high toddler 14 circumference - 7 high child 15 5 circumference - 8 high adult small 17 circumference - 9 high adult 19 5 circumference - 10 high adult extra large 22 circumference - 11 high © 2020 susan plack page 1 needle size 5 for the ribbing ​ size 7 for the body of the hat gauge 5 stitches per inch in pattern ​ supplies yarn darning needle to sew in the ends ​ ​ stitch marker to mark the beginning of the round abbreviations co cast on k knit p - purl p2tog purl 2 stitches together *repeat cast on 60/72/84/96/108/120 stitches ​ newborn to baby/toddler/child/adult small/adult/adult extra large join to knit in the round ribbing k1 p1 for 8/8/9/9/10/10 row place a stitch marker to mark the beginning of the round as you start the ribbing body of the hat note each 6 row repeat adds about 3/4 to the pattern each 6 stitch repeat adds about 1 1/4 to the pattern row 1 - 2 knit you can skip these two row if you want to jump right into the pattern i added them in because the crown is stockinette stitch and i wanted a bit of balance row 3 - 5 * k3 p3 repeat from * to the end row 6 - 8 p3 k3 repeat from * to the end repeat row 3 - 8 and stop when the hat is as tall as you like this is a 6 row repeat i usually measure the height of a hat by my hand from the base of the palm to the tip of the middle finger stop the repeats on either row 5 or row 8 when you reach the height you like some possible recommendations for size please measure and stop when your hat is tall enough ​ newborn to baby repeat row 3
